headline.main: New Growth Charts Dispel the Myth That One Size Fits All

docs.abstract: Article on new standardized growth charts developed from data collected during several recent annual national health and nutrition surveys based on millions of children that better reflect US racial and ethnic diversity and include formula and breast-fed babies; team of nutritionists, pediatricians and statisticians, reporting in January issue of Pediatrics, reports striking improvement in accuracy of charts; graphs; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Like most pediatricians, Dr. Eric Poon usually obtains a child's weight and height during an examination and records them on a set of standardized growth charts. This allows him to compare the child's growth to that of thousands of other children and to determine whether it is adequate, inadequate or, in these times of rampant obesity, too adequate.

headline.main: Maya Children Face Serious Weight Problems

docs.abstract: University of Michigan anthropologist Barry Bogin, addressing American Assn for Advancement of Science symposium on obesity, says survey of 300 Maya children ages 6 to 12 in Florida and California has found that they are three times as likely to be overweight as average American child; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A Maya child growing up in the United States is three times as likely to be overweight as the average American child, according to a new survey conducted by an anthropologist at the University of Michigan at Dearborn. Of about 300 Maya children ages 6 to 12 in Florida and California, 42 percent were overweight based on criteria used by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, compared with just under 15 percent of American children in the same age range, the anthropologist, Dr. Barry Bogin reported.

headline.main: Asking if Obesity Is a Disease or Just a Symptom

docs.abstract: Article on debate among researchers over whether obesity, which some say is becoming epidemic in America, is symptom or disease; some suspect it is symptom and that losing weight does little or nothing for underlying illness; caution against belief that disease can increase chances of developing diabetes or heart disease or dying early; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The obesity warnings are everywhere. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says that with 35 percent of Americans overweight and 27 percent obese, obesity ''has risen at an epidemic rate during the past 20 years.'' In December, Dr. David Satcher, who was surgeon general, said obesity would soon succeed tobacco as the leading cause of preventable deaths in America.

headline.main: Fighting the Lessons Schools Teach on Fat

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on drastic changes that will be necessary to reverse trend toward obesity among America's children; notes restaurants offer ever-larger portions, schools, facing budget constraints, have been cancelling athletic programs and children lead more sedentary lives; notes children learn by example and child's tastebuds can be programmed, in a sense, to prefer healthier foods; views roles of parents and schools as essential; graph (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's children -- indeed, the world's -- are fatter than ever, with no end in sight to their increasing girth, and unless something is done now to reverse this trend, the health costs, already very high, will be astronomical in the not-too-distant future. One-fourth of all school-age children are now overweight and one-eighth are obese, twice the proportions found just two decades ago.
